I.   ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY POLICIES



Hamakua Energy LLC recognizes management's responsibility in protecting it's employees, equipment, property, and the environment against the hazards of an unintentional ammonia release. The safety and health of all employees and the public is very important. The control of accidents has been and will continue to be a basic responsibility of all personnel in the facility.



The Hamakua PSM/RMP program assigns and documents the specific responsibilities for developing, implementing and integrating the OSHA PSM and the EPA RMP standards into its safety program.



The Hamakua PSM/RMP program focuses attention on ""Making PSM/RMP the way we manage our ammonia selective catalytic NOx reduction (SCR/DeNOx) system"" rather than a project we expect to complete and put on the shelf when the filing date has passed.



Hamakua Energy LLC believes that Employee participation is the key to a successful program. Operating level employees, particularly the Operations Superintendent, the Plant Engineer and the System Operators, have been deeply involved in the PSM/RMP program development, implementation and integration and they assume the major responsibility for operating the Honokaa, Hawaii facility safely.



The Hamakua Emergency Response Program has been developed with the complete cooperation and support of the Hilo Fire Department. All Hamakua employees have received documented emergency response training.

II.  STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



Hamakua Energy LLC Manages an SCR Process for NOx Removal. The ammonia storage and use system is a necessity for the production of electric energy. The ammonia storage and use system contains no more than 45,000 pounds of Anhydrous Ammonia. A

nhydrous Ammonia is the only Hazardous Material on site in quantities above the threshold quantity.

Please refer to onsite documentation for Offsite Consequence data



IV. GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



Hamakua Energy LLC complies with the OSHA Process Safety Management for Highly Hazardous Chemicals (PSM) standard relative to anhydrous ammonia. Therefore, this facility has programs to ensure proper operation and maintenance of the ammonia supply and SCR/DeNOx system. Further, SCR/DeNOx system operators have been trained and are knowledgeable in the safe operation of the SCR/DeNOx system.



The ammonia SCR/DeNOx system at this facility has been designed and constructed using good engineering practices and to conform to industry standards. The system includes ammonia detection devices, an emergency shutdown switch located in the DCS logic, alarms actuated by high release concentrations of ammonia, and safety relief valves to avert serious system overpressure. Periodic maintenance on the ammonia system is ensured via the use of a computerized maintenance management system."





V.  5-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



During the past five years this facility has had no significant accidental releases of ammonia.



VI.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN



This power generating facility has procedures in place to respond to the release of a hazardous substance. Employees are trained to evacuate their respective areas in accordance with OSHA 1910.38(a). Coordination with the local volunteer fire department is initiated during an emergency situation. The Hawaii LEPC has been notified regarding the HEP emergency action plan and of the potential nature of an anhydrous ammonia release.





VII. PLANNED CHANGES FOR SAFETY IMPROVEMENT 



Hamakua Energy LLC is committed to continuous improvement of the safety programs for its employees and off-site receptors. Hamakua Energy LLC expects to improve safet

y performance by emphasizing the all elements of their PSM/RMP Program. All recommendations developed during the Process Hazard Analysis were designed to improve the safety performance of the ammonia process. Hamakua Energy LLC expects to evaluate each recommendation in a timely manner and implement, as soon as possible, those recommendations that will reduce the possibility of a release and/or mitigate the consequences of an unintentional release.
